instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no water damage, has a green light but does not power on.  All S5 power rails are present, but all S3 and S0 rails are missing. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing too and I believe this is what is responsible for enabling the S3 rails? Does <CHIP>U1400</CHIP> create <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>  on this machine or is this the SMC?? I am extremely confused-any help would be great.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message: Resistance to GND on 3V42 rails and both RTC Xtal pins?

RESISTANCE not diode! 
How are you turning this on? Are you shorting the power on pads on the board?

<SIGNAL>PP3V42G3H_BOOST</SIGNAL> .596

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message:
duke means he needs units.

22.48 miles per hour, kilometers per second, pounds, ohms, megaohms, degrees celsius etc.. ?

less than 30,000 ohms to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> usually means dead MCP(aka fucked). We can only determine this if we know what those numbers mean

the meter will usually have a little m or a k to denote million(or milli, depending) or thousand

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message:
Now measure from both of the Xtal pins to 3V42 bus.
Xtal pins to GND should be in the Mohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light, No Power
threads.message:
PPBUS, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>?
Does <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> toggle when you short the power pads?
Does <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>(L7260) come high after shorting power pads?
Check all coils for short to GND?
